description: Final semester of a two year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengineering and Bioengineering Science courses. It is required for only BSE majors. It is intended for the spring semester of the Junior year.
name: BIOENGINEERING LAB IV

values.comments:
This is a fourth semester of a two year sequence lab course covering applications related to biotransport, biomedical instrumentation and biological signal & system analysis. The main materials are laboratory handouts and assigned readings on Blackboard. The course is based on group work and includes an extensive, open-ended project with group oral presentation.

Students reported this course to be \"interesting\"and \"rewarding,\" but felt it was disorganized,. With two professors\' different requirements, studying and preparation for the exams were often hard. Creativity was not well encouraged in class. Use of MATLAB was required.

This course was co-taught by Dr. Foster and Dr. Tsourkas. Both professors were good at relating labs to real life applications. Dr. Foster taught the signal-processing section. He was highly praised for his competency, willingness to work with students and good accessibility by email, \"Dr. Foster is the best professor I\'ve had in terms of answering questions and meeting with students.\" However, there were general complaints about his lateness of posting lab manuals, being late to labs, vague write-up instructions and lack of explanation on deducted lab report points.

This is a junior-level course, and is a requirement for bioengineering majors. Prerequisites are BE209 and BE210, and corequisites are BE324 and BE301. Students found this course \"very difficult\". It is estimated to take \"10-15 hours of individual effort from each lab member to finish the reports.\"

The main materials are laboratory handouts and assigned readings on Blackboard. The course is based on group work and includes an extensive, open-ended project with group oral presentation.

Students reported this course to be \"interesting\"and \"rewarding,\" but felt it was disorganized,. With two professors\' different requirements, studying and preparation for the exams were often hard. Creativity was not well encouraged in class. Use of MATLAB was required.

This course was co-taught by Dr. Foster and Dr. Tsourkas. Both professors were good at relating labs to real life applications. Dr. Tsourkas taught the chemical section. Students highly praised his \"well organized lab manuals, a very structured lab write-up format, grading rubric, and availability during lab hours.\"
